snippet: Though jail is considered an effective incentive for parents who are able to pay, critics say punitive policies do not work for those who are poor.
abstract: Warrant for unpaid child support may have played key role in shooting death of Walter S Scott, who chose to flee from officer after being pulled over; had already lost previous job due to two-week jail term for failing to pay child support, and was fearful of losing current one; Scott's death has focused attention on use of jail to pressure parents to pay support, which critics say traps poor men in cycle of debt, unemployment and imprisonment.

byline.original: By FRANCES ROBLES and SHAILA DEWAN
byline.contributor: Frances Robles reported from North Charleston, and Shaila Dewan from New York. Ben Rothenberg contributed reporting from Charleston, S.C.

lead_paragraph: Though jail is considered an effective incentive for parents who are able to pay, critics say punitive policies do not work for those who are poor.

headline.main: Skip Child Support. Go to Jail. Lose Job. Repeat.
headline.print_headline: Skip Child Support. Go to Jail. Lose Job. Repeat.

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: South Carolina Center for Fathers and Families
